Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to allow political parties to make unlimited expenditures in connection with a candidate's general election campaign. This amendment also clarifies that such expenditures are not considered contributions to the candidate. Technical Amendment: Section 315(c)(1) of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended by removing "and subsection (d)". SEC. 2 repeals public financing and spending limits in the Internal Revenue Code and Federal Election Campaign Act. It applies to taxable years after December 31, 1997. SEC. 3 addresses contribution limits for presidential candidates. Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include limitations on contributions to candidates for the office of the United States President. This amendment adds subsection (b) to impose restrictions on contributions despite the existing limitations in subsection (a). The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to impose restrictions on contributions exceeding $10,000 to candidates for the office of the United States President. SEC. 4. Modification of contribution limits; indexing. Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits in subsection (c), with adjustments made to subparagraphs (A) and (C) of paragraph (1) and the rounding of increased amounts to the nearest multiple of $1,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits in subsection (c) for a 2-year period starting after the last general election, with adjustments made to subparagraphs (A) and (C) of paragraph (1) and the rounding of increased amounts to the nearest multiple of $1,000. Additionally, paragraph (2)(B) is updated from "1974" to "1997". SEC. 5. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 by updating the table of chapters to remove chapters 95 and 96 and insert new chapters. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to include changes in various provisions related to political parties. This includes inserting a clarification for national political parties and removing references to specific chapters in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to make changes in provisions related to political parties, including adjustments in section 304(b) and section 306(c) by removing specific references to chapters in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to remove references to chapters in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 in various sections, including section 308 and section 309. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 was amended to remove references to chapters in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 in various sections, including section 309(a)(5)(B), 309(a)(6)(A), 309(a)(6)(C), 309(d)(2), and 309(d)(3). Other amendments included striking references to chapter 95 or chapter 96 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 in sections 309(a)(2) and 309(a)(5)(C), as well as removing certain sentences in sections 311(b) and 314. Additionally, changes were made to section 315(a)(5) by correcting a typographical error. The amendments made to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 removed references to chapters in the Internal Revenue Code of 1954 and eliminated the option for candidates to receive funds under specific chapters. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
